subject: Public Speaking
title: Deductive Reasoning in Speeches
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Deductive Reasoning in Speeches.

hook.text: All humans make mistakes. You are human. Therefore, you will make mistakes. That's deductive logic in three sentences.

buildup.text: Deductive reasoning starts with a general principle, applies it to a specific case. True premises guarantee conclusion.

discovery.text: Lawyers and politicians love deductive arguments because they feel airtight. Accept the premise, accept the conclusion.

twist.text: The weakness: the audience can reject your premise. If the starting principle is wrong, the entire chain crumbles.

climax.text: Deductive arguments are powerful but fragile. They persuade through logic only when both premises are accepted as true.

punchline.text: Strong logic on a weak premise is just elegant nonsense.

quiz.question: What is the weakness of deductive reasoning in speeches?
options: If the audience rejects the premise, the whole argument collapses
